definition:
Let ${\mathfrak{g}}$ be a Lie algebra. Since the sum of any two solvable
ideals of ${\mathfrak{g}}$ is in turn solvable, there is a unique
maximal solvable ideal of any Lie algebra. This ideal is called the
radical of ${\mathfrak{g}}$. Note that
${\mathfrak{g}}/\mathrm{rad}\,{\mathfrak{g}}$ has no solvable ideals,
and is thus semi-simple. Thus, every Lie algebra is an of a semi-simple
algebra by a solvable one.
